thread.title: BHP warns coal miners losing battle for investor, public support
thread.title_full: BHP warns coal miners losing battle for investor, public support

author: David Stringer
title: BHP warns coal miners losing battle for investor, public support
text:
BHP's coal unit had a 3 per cent return on capital from its Australian mines last year as the prices of both metallurgical and thermal coal tumbled. Photo: Peter Braig
 BHP Billiton, the world's biggest exporter of steel-making coal, is concerned the industry is losing the public relations battle to the green lobby for the support of investors and the public.
Coal producers are facing opposition including from environmental groups, Norway's $US830 billion sovereign wealth fund and the Church of England, amid a global campaign that's seen mine projects stalled in court challenges and led investors to cut holdings in some suppliers.
"It would be fair to say that as we stand here today, in the court of public opinion, the 'no coal' camp has been more effective," BHP's coal president Mike Henry said in a prepared text of a speech on Friday. "Anti-coal activism has been building momentum over many years."
"It would be fair to say that as we stand here today, in the court of public opinion, the 'no coal' camp has been more effective," BHP's coal president Mike Henry said. Photo: Michelle Smith
Weaker returns driven by lower prices are reinforcing an incorrect perception that coal's outlook is bleak, Mr Henry said in the text of a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Brisbane. Research "tells us that the industry suffers from declining perceptions in the broader community, particularly outside its direct areas of operation," he said.
Advertisement Melbourne-based BHP's coal unit had a 3 per cent return on capital from its Australian mines last year as the prices of both metallurgical and thermal coal tumbled, and there are "no signs of things getting better in the immediate term," he said.
'Terminal decline' "The poor current profitability of the industry only then serves to reinforce the views and arguments of those who wish to paint the industry as being in terminal decline," Mr Henry said in his speech. The industry's "lack of alignment and coordinated effort has undermined our effectiveness in engaging broader society on the facts," he said.
Coal accounted for 14 per cent of BHP's revenue in the year to June 30, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Anti-coal activists are "abusing" legal challenges to slow the pace of approvals for mine developments or expansions, Rio Tinto Groups's Australia managing director Phil Edmands said last year.
Bloomberg
